construction: A schematic of a full wave rectifier is presented above for you to model. Nodes representing the output of the center-tapped transformer have been given to you.  Construct a model for the rectification portion of the circuit. Diodes CR1 and CR2 are real, having a knee voltage of 0.7 volts. The load resistor RL has a resistance of 1000 ohms. Finish the model and graph the current across the load resistor RL
incremental: This is a model of a full wave rectifier. It includes nodes representing the output of the center-tapped transformer. Diodes CR1 and CR2 are real, having a knee voltage of 0.7 volts. The load resistor RL has a resistance of 1000 ohms.
execution: This is a model of a full wave rectifier. It includes nodes representing the output of the center-tapped transformer. Diodes CR1 and CR2 are real, having a knee voltage of 0.7 volts. The load resistor RL has a resistance of 1000 ohms.
waveform: This is a model of a full wave rectifier. It includes nodes representing the output of the center-tapped transformer. Diodes CR1 and CR2 are real, having a knee voltage of 0.7 volts. The load resistor RL has a resistance of 1000 ohms.

givenModelNodes.name: maximum peak voltage
givenModelNodes.description: Maximum peak value of the voltage source

givenModelNodes.name: Output V
givenModelNodes.explanation: Here's where we combine the voltages from the two sources, upper and lower winding, that were derived separately using superposition.

givenModelNodes.name: V across upper half of secondary winding
givenModelNodes.description: voltage coupled between the upper end of the secondary transformer and center tap

givenModelNodes.name: V across lower half of secondary winding
givenModelNodes.description: voltage coupled between the center tap and the lower end of the secondary winding of the transformer
givenModelNodes.explanation: Because the center tap is at ground, the lower terminal of the secondary winding is negative with respect to the center tap.  That is, as the primary swings positive, the center also swings positive with respect to the lower tap.  However, we view this as the center holding still at zero, then its the lower tap swinging negative.

givenModelNodes.name: V across CR2
givenModelNodes.explanation: If the diode were an open, and the voltage across it were higher than the knee voltage, then the diode would conduct enough current to reduce the voltage to the knee voltage.  On the other hand, if the applied voltage were less than the knee voltage, then the diode would act like an open (i.e., it would not conduct any current) so the voltage across it would be the applied voltage.

givenModelNodes.name: V across CR1
givenModelNodes.explanation: If the diode were an open, and the voltage across it were higher than the knee voltage, then the diode would conduct enough current to reduce the voltage to the knee voltage.  On the other hand, if the applied voltage were less than the knee voltage, then the diode would act like an open (i.e., it would not conduct any current) so the voltage across it would be the applied voltage.

givenModelNodes.name: wavelength
givenModelNodes.description: Length of sine wave input voltage

givenModelNodes.name: Output V from lower
givenModelNodes.description: Output V from lower winding alone
givenModelNodes.explanation:
Using superposition, this variable represents is the output voltage from the lower winding acting through CR2 diode.  There is a loop involving the diode, the lower winding and the load resistor.  This output voltage is the voltage across the load resistor, so by Kirchoff's law, it is (V across lower winding - V across CR2).

Here's another way to look it it. When the lower winding's bottom terminal is positive, then the diode conducts and drops the knee voltage, so this quantity (i.e., output V from lower) is (V across lower winding - V across CR2).     When the lower winding's bottom terminal is negative, then the diode does not conduct, and drops whatever is applied to it, so this quantity (output V from upper) is zero, which is also (V across lower winding - V across CR2).

givenModelNodes.name: Output V from upper
givenModelNodes.description: Output V from upper winding alone
givenModelNodes.explanation:
Using superposition, this is the output voltage from the upper winding acting through CR1 diode.  Using superposition, this variable represents is the output voltage from the upper winding acting through CR1 diode.  There is a loop involving the diode, the upper winding and the load resistor.  This output voltage is the voltage across the load resistor, so by Kirchoff's law, it is (V across upper winding - V across CR1).

Here's another way to look it it. When the upper winding's top terminal is positive, then the diode conducts and drops the knee voltage, so this quantity (output V from upper) is (V across upper winding - V across CR1).     when the upper winding's top terminal is negative, then the diode does not conduct, and drops whatever is applied to it, so this quantity (output V from upper) is zero, which is also (V across upper winding - V across CR1).

givenModelNodes.name: V across CR2 when open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage drop across CR2 when it is reverse biased
givenModelNodes.explanation:
If the diode were an open circuit, then this node represents the voltage drop across the diode measures from left to right.   However, there are two voltage sources in this circuit: the upper and lower windings.  We can user superposition and analyze them separately.  So here we just consider the lower winding as a source.  

If CR2 is open, it just sees the lower winding's voltage on its left and ground on its right, so it's voltage drop left to right is just the lower winding's voltage.

givenModelNodes.name: V across CR1 when open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage drop across diode CR1 when it is reverse biased
givenModelNodes.explanation: Using superposition, we ignore the lower winding and only consider the upper winding as a voltage source.  The drop across CR1 from left to right if it were an open circuit is just the upper winding's voltage because the right side of CR1 would be at ground.

schemas.name: Full Wave Rectifier Behavior
schemas.nodes: id3, id4, id7, id11, id12, id13, id25, id24, id23, id22, id21, id19, id18
